metadata.sermon_start_end: I want to confront your hearts and minds with the subject "the everywhereness of God." Now, you need not arch your eyebrows at that word everywhereness. It will not intimidate me. For the last forty-five years, my landlady has been an affirmative-actionfree, Oberlin College Phi Baker Kappa [...] He will not leave you, not even then.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Psalm 139 as a framework, but it functions more as a thematic springboard for the 'everywhereness' of God rather than an exploration of what this text says that no other text says. It borders on a speech about a biblical 'keyword' or 'idea', which Dekker explicitly warns against.
quotes: When our poet has dealt with our lack of privacy, he then begins to talk about the everywhereness of God
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the unique poetic and theological tension of Psalm 139—the 'inescapablity' of God as both comfort and terror—rather than treating it as a general doctrine of omnipresence.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a brief mention of Israel's trek and local deities, but it lacks depth in Hebrew linguistics or the specific historical-theological context of the Psalter. The exegesis is largely replaced by anecdotes about the preacher's landlady and Russian cosmonauts.
quotes: They were referred to as local deities. They had territorial sovereignty. They were effective on their own turf, but beyond their borders they lacked authority.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Utilize the original Hebrew context of 'Sheol' and 'Shamayim' to ground the spatial metaphors in the ancient Near Eastern worldview instead of modern 'scientism'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (Playboy, Nairobi conference, Russian cosmonauts), which Dekker values. However, it often slips into cultural commentary rather than spiritual application to the specific hearer's life of faith.
quotes: I saw a gentleman on a plane who had hidden in the folds of the New York Daily News a copy of Playboy magazine.
It was a quotation from the chairwoman of the conference on the Decade of the Woman meeting now in Nairobi.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond social commentary to how the 'everywhereness' of God specifically confronts the individual's 'misery' or 'gratitude' in their current vocation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is a mosaic of anecdotes and biblical phrases. While not a 'block' structure (first exegesis, then application), the movement is more associative than an integrated 'exposition-application' of the text itself. The text is often a pretext for the next story.
quotes: And our commentator... looks around as if from alpine heights. I always feel moved... to say, 'I had a Doberman pinscher once...'
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the contemporary examples serve to 'expound' the text's meaning rather than distracting from it.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon touches on misery (the 'sleaziest' revelations, 'filth and foulness') and redemption (Calvary, 'scoops us up'). However, the 'gratitude' part is somewhat lost in general encouragement rather than a response to the Word.
quotes: That he has gotten down in the filth and foulness and vileness of our mortality.
I wish that I could find a nicer word, but he scoops us up out of degradation.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify that the 'misery' is specifically misery 'before God' (lack of privacy) rather than just social 'sleaziness'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon leans heavily toward the 'everywhereness' as a safety net. While it mentions 'hell' and 'destruction', the 'two ways'—the possibility of being lost—is softened by the overarching theme that God is always there regardless of choice.
quotes: ...there is no circumstance, no condition, in which God is not present.
He will not leave you, not even then.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the 'seriousness of choice' by addressing how fleeing from God's presence (the 'broad way') constitutes a real temporal or eternal loss.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Strongest point. The sermon moves toward Christ as the telos, specifically connecting the 'descent into hell' of the Psalm to the Creed and the Incarnation. Grace is presented as the deepest reality.
quotes: The heart of the whole biblical revelation is that God has come... That is the very meaning of the Incarnation.
At Calvary, God in Christ has reached out to the farthest edges...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'theme' added at the end but the lens through which the 'everywhereness' of the Father is understood from the start.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes (1850 words), it falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum for 'depth'. The breadth is achieved through anecdotes rather than theological 'breadth' of the text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the substantive theological reflection on the 'two natures' or the 'three parts' to reach the 20-minute threshold of depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a rhetorical 'speech' on the theme of omnipresence than a strict 'exposition and application' of Psalm 139. It relies heavily on anecdotal evidence and cultural critique (Playboy, Nairobi, Doberman pinschers) which, while concrete, often obscures the specific voice of the text. It lacks the rigorous exegesis (Hebrew/Greek) Dekker demands and softens the 'two ways' into a general assurance of presence.
strengths: Concrete contemporary application that engages the zeitgeist.
Clear Christological telos, linking the Psalm to the Incarnation and the Creed.
Vivid language and metaphors that avoid 'feeble' or 'passive' speech.
weaknesses: Insufficient exegesis of the original context and specific uniqueness of the passage.
Thematic approach (omnipresence) rather than textual actualization.
Duration falls below the 20-minute threshold for 'depth'.
Absence of the 'seriousness of being lost' (Thesis 6).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong rhetorical performance, but a weak 'sermon' by Dekker's standards. It prioritizes the preacher's anecdotes over the text's specific 'nowhere else' quality. It is more a 'speech about an idea' than a 'recreation of the Bible into a new, current, proclamatory word'.
